editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the friendly Readers, both Gentlemen and Gentlewomen, Wealth and Welfare.
div.p:
GEntlemen & GentlewomeÃÑ, I pre≈øent you here (as I think) a profitable vnpoli≈øhed labor: For, he that is the Trouchman of a ≈øtrangers toung, may wel declare his meaning, but yet ≈øhall marre the grace of his Tale: And therefore, Themi≈øtocles the noble Captayne and Philo≈øopher of Athens, compareth ≈øuch forced ≈øpeeches, to Tapi≈øtrie Hangings rowled vp: which being open, appeare beatifull: and foulded, re≈øerue their Vertue, but lo≈øe their ≈øhew: But I expect (≈øomwhat) a better euent, then may an Interpreter, that is bound to a pre≈øent Reporte: for my Re≈øpit hath been ≈øufficient to con≈øider of Segnior Philoxenus, and his honourable companies vertues: and (lea≈øt by ra≈øh acquital of their fauours, I ≈øhould doe iniurie to their reputation) I haue with well adui≈øed Iudgement, bethought me of ≈øuch memorable Que≈øtions and deuices, as I heard and ≈øaw pre≈øented, in this mo≈øt noble Italian Gentlemans Pallace, the Chri≈øtmas pa≈øt: and an≈øwerable to my weake capacitie, haue expo≈øed the ≈øame, in ≈øuch ≈øorte, as if you be not too curious, may delight and content you: and if not too carele≈ø≈øe, may direct and benefite you: And to ≈øatisfie you herein, I giue you friendly knowlehge, that Segnior Philoxenus reuerent regarde of the Queenes Maie≈øties high vertues, is a pre≈øident for you; with a dutiful, and vnfayned heart, to loue, feare, and obey her Highne≈ø≈øe, from whom, next vnder God, you receiue ≈øuch ble≈ø≈øings, as throgh the whole world her excellencie is renowmed, and your pro≈øperitie enuied. By this noble Gentlemans ciuill entertainement of ≈øtraungers, you may perceiue with what Garland, Courte≈øie is principall, crowned: By the ciuill behauiours of Soran≈øo, Dondolo, Bargetto, and other Gentlemen herein named, you haue a Pre≈øident of gouernment, which will commend you: and by well regarding their ≈øpeeches, you ≈øhal finde a di≈øcreet methode of talke, meete for you Gentlemen. The like benefite, ≈øhall Gentlewomen receiue in imitating of Madona Aurelia, (Queene of the Chri≈øtmas plea≈øures) Maria Beloch ‚Ä¢ , Lucia Bella, France≈øchina Sancta,
and the re≈øt of the well qualited Gentlewomen. Be≈øides, a number of other Moral documents, needful reprehen≈øions, and wittie ≈øayings, to perfect the commendation both of a Gentleman and Gentlewoman. (Courteous Gentlemen and Gentlewomen) you haue here the honorable in≈øtitution of Mariage, ≈øo perfectly Anatomed, as a very weake iudgement may ≈øee the cau≈øes, which make hou≈øholde quarrels to re≈øemble Hell. Agayne, the man which is willing to liue happily, may here learne ≈øuch directions and lawes, as will change his priuate hou≈øe into a Paradi≈øe on earth. If ciuil & Moral plea≈øures, with al the≈øe benefites, may make you entertayne this booke, and report wel of the Author, I a≈ø≈øure you, you ≈øhalbe plea≈øed, and I ≈øatisfied. But if you make your tongue enemie to your owne reputation, you may detract, but not reproch the work: Iniure, but not hurt the writer, for both will liue, and laugh ≈øuch Calumniators to ≈øcorne, when either are ready to doe the di≈øcreete Reader ≈øeruice.

Some wil (perchance more of enuy to heare a ≈øtranger commended, then of pitie to bemone my hard fortune, or fowle v≈øage) ≈øay, I haue as iu≈øt cau≈øe to complaine of iniuries receiued at Roane, Rome, and Naples, as to commend the vertues and good entertainmeÃÑt of Segnior Philoxenus: But to giue ≈øuch ≈øugge≈øtioners a double good example, both of patience and thankfulne≈ø≈øe: I here prote≈øt, that as the≈øe iniuries begunne, with my hard fortune, ≈øo they ended no wayes in my di≈øcredite: And as I forgiue the cau≈øes of my mi≈øhaps, ≈øo ≈øcorne I to recount them, to receiue amends, in a little pitie. But for that they, and all ≈øuch as view my reporte, may learne of me to be gratefull for receiued benefites: I make it knowen, that this trauel is Segnior Philoxenus due: And I ≈øtill his debtor, and ≈øo ≈øhall remayne during my life: re≈øeruing a good affection, to be≈øtow on ≈øuch as receiue his Vertues: and my paynes to profite and commend them≈øelues. And in my opinion, it is iu≈øt they doe ≈øo: Wherefore, to giue a di≈øgrace to ceremonies, Gentlemen and Gentlewomen, I end: as I hope to finde you friendly.

Now, touching the generall di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øuch women, as from the cart, are ray≈øed vnto this account: they will v≈øe the

Sir (quoth Dondola) without offence, either to your per≈øon

div.p: BY that time Supper was done, certaine Commedians of Reuenna, pre≈øented their ≈øeruice to Segnior Philoxenus, and his honourable companie, who are not tied to a written deuice, as our Engli≈øh Players are, but hauing certaine grounds or principles of their owne will, Extempore, make a plea≈øant ≈øhowe of other mens fanta≈øies: ≈øo that to trie the quicknes of the Gentlemen, and Gentlewomens wittes, to giue the Comedians a theame, Segnior Philoxenus, demanded the meaning of certaine Que≈øtions.

Couetou≈ønes. and therefore vnlikely to be friend to others: al≈øo is but a Steward of his goods he gathereth, for he ≈øpareth for others, and ≈øpendeth little or nothing vpon him≈øelfe: and at the iudgement day, before GOD, mu≈øt make account of all his deceit.

div.head: The worthie, Hi≈øtorie of Phrigius and Pieria Reported by Segnior Philoxenus.
div.p: IN the Regi≈øter of Fame, wherein the Monuments of the vertuous are Cronicled, as pre≈øidents for their po≈øteritie, I read, that in the famous Cittie of Miletum in Ionia, as ≈øoueraigne Prince and Gouernour, there raigned a worthie Duke called Nebeus, who to comfort and ≈øupport his aged y√©eres, had to his Sonne and onely heire, Phrigius, a yong Gentleman of ≈øuch rare towardliues, as it may be a que≈øtion, whether he were more beholding to Nature for the perfections of his body, to Vertue for ye qualities of his minde, or to Fortune in ≈øuffering him to be ≈øo nobly borne.

The Captaines of Myos encouraged their Souldiers of the one part, but the Souldiers of Miletum were driuen to comfort their Captaine with a threatning of di≈øgrace. But ah poore Phrigius, what an≈øwere ≈øhould≈øt thou make? to ≈ø√©e thy Souldiers ≈ølaine, and thy citties ≈øpoyled, without proffers of re≈øcue were di≈øhonourable: to bend thy forces again≈øt thy owne hart, were vnnatural: to make the be≈øt choi≈øe of the≈øe two euils, required lea≈øure, and iudgement. Ah traiterous eyes, betraiers of my whole body, the ≈øcourge of Miletum, and enemies of my honour: the vengeance of Oedipus is too gentle for your iniuries: what doo≈øt thou ≈øay? oh bla≈øphemous tung, riuall of humanitie, calumner of Beautie, and hinderer of thy Countries peace: thou reprocher of vertue, and Phrigius welfare: know to thy ≈øhame, the perfection of my eyes haue con≈øtantly behelde Pieria, who≈øe deuine beauties, emblemed in humane ≈øhape, dazeleth the yonge≈øt ≈øight in Ionia. Then to reuile them thus, thou tiranni≈øie≈øt nature: to demaund why I loue and ≈øerue Beautie, thy que≈øtion is blinde, and de≈øerueth a double

O cruel Warre, thou art not vnproperly called the ≈øcourge of God,The vengance of Warre. for in th√©e is contained a greater vengeance then might be imagined by man: thou arme≈øt the Sonne again≈øt the Father, the Vnckle again≈øt the Nephewe, the Subiect again≈øt his Soueraigne: Thy drinke is blood, thy foode the fle≈øh of men, thy fiers are flming Citties, thy plea≈øures ≈øpoyling of Widdowes, rau i≈øhment of Virgins, ≈øubuer≈øion of Lawes and publique benefite: thy Iudges, Tiranny and Iniu≈øtice: and where thou remaine≈øt, her knowne enemy is not ≈øo dangerous, as the fained fr√©end.

O yes: and Phrigius the ≈øeruant of Venus? too true: is it then impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould agr√©e in affection? yea ≈øure. O vnfortunate Phrigius, through peace which receiued≈øt thy wound before Dianas Alter, and by cruell warre art ≈øeperated from the Surgion that ≈øhould cure th√©e. The≈øe ≈øundry conflicts Phrigius had with his bitter pa≈ø≈øions, which pur≈øued their aduaÃÑ tage, with ≈øuch thornie feares, as if he had not b√©ene ≈øuddenly ≈øuccoured, by the adui≈øe and comfort of Lord Miletus a fauoured Coun≈øeller to Duke Nebeus, and an a≈ø≈øured fr√©end to his ≈øonne Phrigius, he had b√©ene like to haue y√©elded to di≈øpaire. Miletus was glad to ≈ø√©e him thus affected, and ≈øorry to beholde him ≈øo dangerou≈øly afflicted: for in this loue he fore≈øawe an end, of the ancient enuie and enmitie, betw√©ene the Citizens of Miletum and Myos: who≈øe ciuill Fraies had buried more yong men in the F√©eldes, then aged in the Churches and Churchyardes. Therefore to confirme his affection, and to comfort him with hope: Lord Phrigius quoth he, to blame your affection, were cruelty and no ≈øound coun≈øell: for you loue Pieria the Paragon of the worlde, to di≈øcomfort you with an impo≈ø≈øibilitie of her fauour, were clean again≈øt the po≈ø≈øibilitie of your fortune: for be≈øides that, your per≈øon alluringly plea≈øeth, your authorities commaund: yea Pithes cannot but reioyce, Pieria con≈øent, and all Myos de≈øire is to ≈øolemnize this Mariage.

My ≈øelfe and the grauer ≈øort of the coun≈øell, will motion the matter to the Duke your Father, who I tru≈øt wil holde the affection of his ≈øonne, rather to proc√©ede from the iu≈øtice of Diana, then the iniurie of Cupid. Who regarding the zelous offering ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢
Pieria, agreed that you ≈øhould be wounded, that Pieria might haue the honour to cure you, in who≈øe vertues all Ionia hopeth to be ble≈ø≈øed. Therefore, to make your affection knowen, in ≈øome plea≈øing Letter, to Pieria coÃÑ mend your ≈øeruice, and to deale with both your Fathers, refer the care to me: How ≈øw√©ete the ≈ømalle≈øt hope of grace is to a condemned man: or the lea≈øt word of comfort, from

body.head: Phrigius Letter to Pieria.
body.p: FAire Pieria, ≈øith it is a common thing to loue: and a miracle to ≈øubdue affection, let it not ≈øeeme ≈øtrange, that I am ≈ølaue to your beautie, nor wonder though I ≈øue for grace.
